title: The AI Behind AI: Turing's Impact on the Coding Race
description: In this episode, we dive into how a startup named Turing is powering the coding abilities of AI giants like OpenAI, Google, and Anthropic, and why coding has become the key skill for large language models.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Hello and welcome to another episode of 'life is artificial', where we explore the cutting edge of technology, innovation, and what the future could look like.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Today, we're going to take a deep dive into a fascinating story about AI, coding, and how a relatively small player is making waves in the world of artificial intelligence—helping giants like OpenAI and Google stay competitive in the ever-evolving AI landscape. The story comes from an article titled 'The Startup Fueling OpenAI and Anthropic’s Coding Race,' published by The Information.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Imagine a world where the ability of an AI to write code is not just a tool for developers, but also a benchmark for how well it can answer other, unrelated questions. This is exactly what's happening in the world of large language models, or LLMs. The better an LLM can code, the more rigorous its reasoning abilities become, and, as a result, the more capable it becomes at answering questions across a wide range of domains.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: And this is where Turing comes into play. Turing is a startup that’s providing on-demand access to part-time software engineers who are being leveraged by some of the biggest names in AI—OpenAI, Google, Anthropic, Microsoft, and more—to improve their AI models' coding capabilities.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: The journey began when OpenAI started using Turing's coders to evaluate and improve their models for coding tasks. You might wonder, why coding? According to the article, improving coding capabilities actually enhances an AI model's ability to answer other types of questions effectively. Coding, with its precise logic and requirements for structured thinking, trains these models to become more reliable in generating answers across all sorts of contexts.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: This competitive advantage did not go unnoticed. Google was quick to follow suit, striking a multimillion-dollar deal with Turing to put hundreds of programmers to work evaluating their AI models. Google knew they were behind OpenAI, and they wanted to catch up. In a matter of months, Turing had over 500 programmers working on thousands of coding tasks to improve Google’s AI models.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: The results of these collaborations have led Turing to experience substantial growth, with annualized revenue projected to hit $240 million this year. Turing has become one of the essential partners in the AI ecosystem, joining the likes of Scale AI and Surge AI, which are also key players providing human raters to improve AI models.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: But it's not just coding. Turing is now expanding beyond coding, offering professionals from various fields like marketing, finance, and healthcare to evaluate and enhance AI models' performance. This means that AI developers are looking to automate tasks across industries, and they need the expertise of real professionals to do it.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: In the grand scheme of things, Turing is positioning itself not just as a service for AI developers, but as a competitor to consulting firms like Accenture or Boston Consulting Group. Their remote-first model, lower overhead, and flexibility make them an attractive alternative to the traditional consulting giants, especially for businesses seeking a more cost-effective solution.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Turing's approach involves what CEO Jonathan Siddharth calls the 'dark art of AI'—post-training. It's a phase where human testers work with AI models, identifying their strengths and weaknesses, and fine-tuning them for release. This intricate dance between human insight and machine learning has proven to be a crucial factor in making models like ChatGPT more effective, particularly for developers.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: For Siddharth, Turing is also a personal mission. He saw firsthand how good software programmers from countries like India, Pakistan, Brazil, and Argentina were being overlooked due to a lack of economic opportunity. Turing is leveraging this untapped global talent pool to provide opportunities to these programmers while helping AI giants shape the future of technology.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: So, why is coding such a pivotal part of this AI race? It’s because coding demands precision, structured logic, and a depth of reasoning. Training an AI to code isn't just about writing software—it’s about training an AI to think better. And in the end, a model that can handle the structured complexity of coding can more reliably help across a wide range of tasks.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: As we see the field evolve, it’s clear that the collaboration between human intelligence and artificial intelligence is still very much at the core of these advances. Human coders are teaching these models, and the models are, in turn, becoming more capable assistants to us all. The relationship is symbiotic, and startups like Turing are right at the center of this transformation.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: That's it for today’s episode. If you want to learn more, check out the original article from The Information. The link is in the episode description. I hope you enjoyed this glimpse into the behind-the-scenes work that’s driving the AI revolution forward. Stay tuned for more episodes on the future of technology, innovation, and, of course, artificial life.

script.speaker: Host
script.text: Until next time, take care, and keep your mind curious!
